greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of different ways to represent n as general polygonal number P(m,r) = 1/2*r*((m-2)*r-(m-4)) = n>1, for m,r>1.
comment: The indices k of the first appearance of number n in a(k) are listed in A063778(n) = {2,3,6,15,36,225,...} = Least number k>1 such that k could be represented in n different ways as general m-gonal number P(m,r) = 1/2*r*((m-2)*r-(m-4)).

Also the number of integer partitions of n whose augmented differences are all equal, where the augmented differences aug(y) of an integer partition y of length k are given by aug(y)_i = y_i - y_{i + 1} + 1 if i < k and aug(y)_k = y_k; for example aug(6,5,5,3,3,3) = (2,1,3,1,1,3). Equivalently, a(n) is the number of integer partitions of n whose differences are all equal to the last part minus one. The Heinz numbers of these partitions are given by A307824. For example, the a(35) = 5 partitions are:
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..10000
E. Deza and M. Deza, Figurate Numbers, World Scientific, 2012; see p. 45.
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Polygonal Number
Gus Wiseman, Sequences counting and ranking integer partitions by the differences of their successive parts.
formula: G.f.: x * Sum_{k>=1} x^k / (1 - x^(k*(k + 1)/2)) (conjecture). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Apr 09 2020
maple: A129654 := proc(n) local resul, dvs, i, r, m ;
for i from 1 to nops(dvs) do
mathematica: a[n_] := (dvs = Divisors[2*n]; resul = 0; For[i = 1, i <= Length[dvs], i++, r = dvs[[i]]; If[r > 1, m = (2*n/r-4+2*r)/(r-1); If[IntegerQ[m], resul = resul+1 ] ] ]; resul); Table[a[n], {n, 2, 106}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Sep 13 2012, translated from _R. J. Mathar_'s Maple program *)
Table[Length[Intersection[Divisors[2 n - 2] + 1, Divisors[2 n]]], {n, 2, 106}] (* _Jonathan Sondow_, May 09 2014 *)
results.author: _Alexander Adamchuk_, Apr 27 2007
